CodeExtractoR

Source: vignettes/vignette.Rmd
vignette.Rmd

Introduction

A number of articles written in PDF files contain code snippets. These are usually just a method to achieve results presented in the paper. However, a curious user might want to run these codes for himself - to replicate the results, experiment for themselves or for other reasons. Unfortunately, the process of extracting code manually might prove long, boring and prone to mistakes. Some articles are submitted with supplementary material with code files, although (in case of RJournal) it’s just a recent development:

For articles published longer ago, the extraction of the code is left to the user.

Package CodeExtractoR

With package CodeExtracoR the code may be extracted in a manner of seconds:

library(CodeExtractoR)
my_url <- "https://journal.r-project.org/archive/2014/RJ-2014-011/RJ-2014-011.pdf"
api_key <- "my_api_key"
extract_code_from_pdf(my_url, output_file = "output.R", api_key = api_key)

It uses API to cloudconvert to convert pdf to html file, and extracts code from html based on its unique font. Therefore, package will not work on files, where code font is non-standard.

Obtaining your own API key to cloudconvert (version 1) is suggested - registration is free and the API free plan should be more than sufficient. The user might also convert the pdf file manually and use it instead:

extract_code_from_html('input.html', 'output.R')

Package will work only on HTML files created with cloudconvert or any other converter using pdf2htmlex.

Customization

Most of the code commands start with a character (like ‘>’ or ‘R>’). You may supply the console_char argument to extract_* function specifing it. Then, all the lines starting with it (or +) will be treated as lines of code to run and all the others as output of the code - and they will be automatically commented out.

extract_code_from_html('input.html', 'output.R', console_char = '>')
